svcsubsecinfo.para: Automatic radiator shutters control ram air flow to the radiator by closing and opening rapidly in response to fluctuations in the coolant temperature. This effectively keeps the engine within the OPTIMUM TEMPERATURE RANGE.

With the vehicle shut down, the shutter vanes are always open. When a cold engine is started, the shutter vanes close to block ram air flow so the engine will heat up rapidly. When the coolant has heated to the high temperature limit, the sensor on the shutter control (solenoid) valve closes ( Figure 3and Figure 4). This cuts off the (air or hydraulic) pressure to the shutter control cylinder, and the shutter vanes open.

With the vanes open, ram air flows through the radiator and around the engine, lowering the coolant temperature. The shutter vanes close when the low temperature limit is reached. The cycle repeats as frequently as necessary to keep the engine within the correct temperature range.

note.para: If more air flow (cooling effect) is needed than open shutter vanes provide, the fan clutch or viscous fan drive engages. When the low temperature limit is reached, the fan operation stops before the vanes close. This cycle also repeats as needed.
